voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Grim Fandango is one of my personal favorite games of all time. I've finished it twice in the 4 days since I purchased the game and I can definitely say I recieved my money's worth.

You play as Manny Calavera, a travel agent for in the land of the dead. In your adventure you must save the woman you love, foil a mob boss' plans and lead a resistance against the corruption in the D.O.D. It will take you around 12 hours (dependant on how long it takes you to figure out puzzles) and it has some of the most clever and funny writing I've seen in a game. This was Tim Shaffer's last project at LucasArts and It is still one of his best.

Although the title says Remastered" you're not getting a huge face-lift akin to "The Secret of Monkey Island Special Edition" or "DuckTales Remastered". It's really just a few fixes to some lack-luster textures to make them look more appealing. If you want to play the game with the original graphics you can change between versions with the simple click of a button.

All in all
date: It is definitely worth your time and money if you're a fan of funny writing
recommended: difficult puzzles and adventure games. I highly recommend Grim Fandango to old fans and new comers alike."

reviewText:
A brilliant game that will provide you with around 8-12 hours of gameplay depending how good you are with puzzles. This game is of course remastered and looks alot smoother for it. There is a toggle option so that you can see how the game looked when it first came out but is not necessary for any in game unlockables or steam achievments.

You will like this game if you are a fan of other puzzles games such as the monkey island series but some of the puzzles can be unobvious as to what needs to be done and may well take up more time than you expect. That being said this game is well worth the time that you will invest and the story line is solid and will also provide you with many laughs along the way.

I recommend this game out of personal preference but i would most certainly agree that this game will only be fun for a specific audience and/or to gamers who have patience and can listen closely to dialog. Sometimes the clues that you need will be in the dialog options that you choose and these clues can be obvious... but some of them will be a little more cryptic.

reviewText: This is my first time ever playing this game, and considering the fact that it used to cost a small fortune to play it legally, I'm personally just happy that we got it back at all. Prior to this, I'd heard nothing but praise for this gem of an adventure game, and I'm very pleased to share that my expectations were met within an hour of playtime, and then exceeded over the next fifteen. Now that I've finished, I'm having a great deal of trouble deciding where in my top five favourite games of all time it would fall, and I'd call that a good problem to have. Yes, it's kind of cheating to critique the game itself and not the remaster, but I'm sure there are thousands of others like me who are going to have the pleasure of experiencing Grim Fandango for the first time because of this new release. That's something we can all appreciate, isn't it?

reviewText:
Re-playing the most memorable game from your childhood is always going to be risky but I am pleased to say that none of my love for Grim Fandango has diminished over the years. It is still as witty, imaginative and charming as I remembered it.

In fact, other than a few changes to the lighting, slight smoothing of textures and some very pointless Steam achievements, it is EXACTLY as I remembered it! The devs even left some of the bugs in for nostalgia reasons it seems.

The best thing about the remastering is that it works on all OS, meaning I can finally play it again after all these years and enjoy it just as I did way back then. If you've never played this masterpiece, you are in for a treat.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I bought this game when it first came out. I bought it again when it hit the bargain bins, just in case the first set of discs ever got scratched. I still have both of those sets of CDs. Now I've bought it a third time on Steam.

A true classic. Probably the first videogame to make me think seriously about the potential of games as art. I think the Year 3 to Year 4 transition cutscene is still as close as I've ever come to actually weeping at a game [EDIT: Nope, now I have to give that particular accolade to The Beginner's Guide"].

Regarding the lack of true widescreen support: I don't consider it a problem
date: any more than I would consider the lack of a widescreen option on a Casablanca DVD to be a problem. It was originally created and intended for a 4:3 screen. Even if they had been able to re-render all the backgrounds in true H+ widescreen
recommended: playing it that way ought to warn you at the start: "This game has been modified from its original version. It has been formatted to fit your screen.""

reviewText:
Grim Fandango!!

One of the best point and click games of all time!!

Pros-
Great Story (totally different from other point and click stories around the time this came out)
Epic and funny characters
Gameplay is simple and straight forward
Good vairety of level design.

Cons:
For a remastered game...it kinda just looks like they made the characters skins HD and cleaned up the interface to be more easier to use (not like it was hard to use to begin with) and that was it... looks totally like the orginal game apart from these two changes.

Graphics are dated but it doesnt bother me this is one of the first pc games i ever played and I love it XD so i am a little biased but for those new to the game be warned the graphics aint pretty XD.

Overall an absoulte classic game!!!

7/10

reviewText:
DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine
Buenos Días, my most favourite quote from my most beloved LucasArts game and my first ever adventure game to play when I was a young child on Windows 95! Grim Fandango has always been by my heart as one of my most beloved LucasArts adventure games of all time! Along with Tales from Monkey Island and Full Throttle! This has to be my third time playing Grim Fandango, and this time as a full remastered edition! First time was back in 2002 when I still had my Windows 95 PC, this was my first ever adventure game that I played along with my stupid educational games. Second time was when I rediscovered my original Grim Fandango CD-ROM game in 2010 and now again in 2015 for the remastered edition!

Grim Fandango's story is brilliant. From its quirky characters to its lovable cutscenes and funny comedy. The characters such as Manuel Calavera and Glottis will surely make you fall in love with them! The music (especially in the remastered edition) is absolutely brilliant and resembles very much Spanish and Mexican music! The cutscenes are lovable and fun to watch, overall the game is brilliant!

The puzzles and game progression, although when I was young and I played Grim Fandango for the very first time I did not have any walkthroughs or guides, hell I didn't even have internet back in 2002, so the puzzles were a bit challenging and can be a bit too awkward for modern-day players or even newcomers to the genre. The game does not help you at all when progressing through and does not hold your hand when your stuck on a puzzle for too long, so be prepared to get stuck here and there, thankfully I remembered most of the stuff! Lucky guys with internet nowadays, you can simply type in walkthroughs for the game!

The remastered version, Double Fine have really done a job well done for remastering this classic. The music is spot-on and digitally remastered. The cutscenes, although not fully converted to HD are very watchable, and the new HUD system they implemented has made it easier for players to play the game (honestly, the game's original controls were clunky and very awkward, surprisingly you can still play with the old controls!). The addition of HD graphics and shadow textures, etc... made the game more stunning than it originally was (and if you want some nostalgia, you can play the game in its original graphics!)

The thing that put me off slightly was the aspect ratio, this game is not tailored for 16:9 monitors and it seems that Double Fine did not optimize the game for 16:9 monitors but kept it at 4:3 aspect ratio, you can still change the aspect ratio from its original 4:3 to 16:9, but you might have to play the game stretched out.

Overall, Grim Fandango and its remastered version are simply brilliant and if you are a fan of LucasArts (like me!) or you like adventure games or you want to try something new, then I would highly recommend playing Grim Fandango and I hope that Double Fine will continue to remaster these old LucasArts classics!

- Guess they couldn't save me, eh?
- No, but there's still a chance you could save me...

RECOMMENDED :)  THEPCGAMER'S BEST GAME IN STEAM LIBRARY! (What's this? :- Like some games get Best Game of 2014" or "Best Indie Game"
date: etc... So I have decided to make my own!)"

reviewText: This is one of my favorite games of all times. Having reached the last chapter I can say that the remastered version doesn't leave much to desire, as far as I can tell. Other reviewers noticed bugs similar to the old version of the game. I didn't notice these and in comparison to the old version the remastered one runs smoothly and without any issues on my system. I can't exclude the possibility of bugs for everyone out there of course. Another criticism in the reviews has been that the remastering hardly added anything new. Well, I guess this had to be expected and as far as I am concerned I welcome it in this case. I never thought the game itself had to be improved much, graphicwise or soundwise, as it is pretty much timeless. Compare it to watching a Silent movie maybe. They can be improved by removing artifacts or restoring parts in which the filmmaterial was decomposed by chemical processes over time. However a good restoration of a Silent movie won't add colour or sound to the movie. This is the Grim Fandango rendering to preserve one of the best Lucas Arts Adventures of all time for present times and (hopefully) for the future. Personally I love being able to revisit all the great settings and characters, the voice-acting is still impeccable and I think there are only a handful of games that are on a similar level even today. Grim Fandango remains an awesome game-experience to play through and I just can't recommend it enough.

reviewText:
It is the city of the dead, corruption is afoot in the Department of Death, a mysterious lady comes and abruptly leaves, and only a clever salesman working off his time in the afterlife is in the right place at the right time to investigate.  This is a film noir story set in the land of the dead.  Appropriately, it is almost entirely filled with a Latin American cast and had heavy doses of Aztec references.

Highly recommended.  A classic Tim Schafer game, this is an adventure set in the center of absurdity.  Burning beavers, crime boses, skeleton birds that still fly, and a spirit of the mechanic who has an urge for speed and an insatiable drive to turn a herse into a hotrod.  I used a guide in a lot of places get me through before impatience set in, and it didn't detract much from my experience.  Sure, I didn't the feeling of an adventure solved on my own, but neither did I spend a couple dozen hours figuring out exactly who to talk to with what item at a certain time.

The story, characters, scripting, voice acting, and music are top notch.  This remaster of an old game, in my opinion, stands above newer adventure games like the Deponia series.  Grim Fandango Remastered is entertaining, clever, sometimes outright hilarious, and well worth a playthrough.

reviewText:
A brilliant game that will provide you with around 8-12 hours of gameplay depending how good you are with puzzles. This game is of course remastered and looks alot smoother for it. There is a toggle option so that you can see how the game looked when it first came out but is not necessary for any in game unlockables or steam achievments.

You will like this game if you are a fan of other puzzles games such as the monkey island series but some of the puzzles can be unobvious as to what needs to be done and may well take up more time than you expect. That being said this game is well worth the time that you will invest and the story line is solid and will also provide you with many laughs along the way.

I recommend this game out of personal preference but i would most certainly agree that this game will only be fun for a specific audience and/or to gamers who have patience and can listen closely to dialog. Sometimes the clues that you need will be in the dialog options that you choose and these clues can be obvious... but some of them will be a little more cryptic.

reviewText:
Grim Fandango is one of my personal favorite games of all time. I've finished it twice in the 4 days since I purchased the game and I can definitely say I recieved my money's worth.

You play as Manny Calavera, a travel agent for in the land of the dead. In your adventure you must save the woman you love, foil a mob boss' plans and lead a resistance against the corruption in the D.O.D. It will take you around 12 hours (dependant on how long it takes you to figure out puzzles) and it has some of the most clever and funny writing I've seen in a game. This was Tim Shaffer's last project at LucasArts and It is still one of his best.

Although the title says Remastered" you're not getting a huge face-lift akin to "The Secret of Monkey Island Special Edition" or "DuckTales Remastered". It's really just a few fixes to some lack-luster textures to make them look more appealing. If you want to play the game with the original graphics you can change between versions with the simple click of a button.

All in all
date: It is definitely worth your time and money if you're a fan of funny writing
recommended: difficult puzzles and adventure games. I highly recommend Grim Fandango to old fans and new comers alike."

When this first came out, it wasn't available for sale where I lived so I missed it.... 17 years later (!) was it everything I imagined it to be?  Oh yes!  Absolutely brilliant.  The story.  The characters. The graphics.  The musical score.  The puzzles.  Unquestionably one of the best games of all time.  If you haven't played it, do yourself a favour and do so.  Immediately.

As an added bonus, I got to play it through with my daughter (aged 8).  This is what she thought about it : “I liked Glotis the big, silly demon.  I also liked the train to the other world.  I liked the love story between Meche and Manny.  I really loved the imagination!”

So there you go, fun for the whole family!

reviewText:
Excellent game. In fact, everything about this game is excellent (minus one thing - more on that later). I'd played this when it originally came out and apart from some vague recollections about having to run all around a 1940s noirish city (Year 2), didn't recall much about it. Which is good. Apparently it's also good I no longer recall the original tank control system, haha.

You play as Manny Calavera, a Department of Death agent charged with selling travel packages to newly-departed souls in order to get them across the land of the dead and to their eternal reward. Except Manny's been getting so many less-than-stellar clients lately he decides to take things into his own (skeletal) hands and catch himself a real do-gooder, sure to qualify for the best package possible (and net Manny a big commission he can use towards paying off his own debt incurred by not leading such a stellar life). But things don't go as planned and Manny ends up trekking across the land of the dead, searching for the client that got away, trying to right all the wrongs that are being done by his department.

A fascinatingly original story, combining Aztec/Mexican underworld myths with 1940s film noir, the game is broken up into four sections, each spanning a year in Manny's travels (though you're not playing through the whole year, thank goodness!). My favorite is easily Year 2, set in the city of Rubacava, where Manny finds himself the head of his very own cafe straight out of Casablanca - complete with piano player and gambling gendarme! There's also unionizing seabees (who are literally bees, heh), beatniks, and the big boss of the competing (and much more successful) gambling joint who has his own problems with women and underlings.

Years III & IV don't seem as long or as involved as Year II, but maybe that's because they're not rooted in one spot and take place in many different locations. Year I is a lot of set-up (well-done setup) of the world and the main players and mystery, and is just fine, except I always wondered why Manny feels so compelled to climb that flag-thing so many times and for no apparent reason haha.

The graphics are beautiful and full of things to click on/interact with, the music is amazing, the characters' personalities are distinctive and their motivations consistent (and they don't feel like set-pieces for Manny to use or manipulate, even though he is doing that a lot of the time), the dialogue/narration is believable and I love how when Manny is directed to look at or use something, his narration (which is obviously for the benefit of the player) is sometimes overheard by surrounding characters who will then respond (though not to the point where they wonder why he's talking to himself so much tee hee).

The voice acting in this game is some of the best I've ever heard. Tony Plana is such a perfect Manny that I've never forgotten him and can easily spot him whenever he shows up on TV or in films (or at the theatre where I once worked!). Glottus is also great fun to listen to, as are the shady characters in Year II. And I can always spot Kay Kuter too (I know him from Gabriel Knight II).

There were a couple times I had to consult hints (which I hate doing, argh). In Year I, because of a pixel-hunting failure on my part. In year II, because I failed to connect what I saw in a picture with a line of dialogue I'd heard much earlier. Year III, I was frustrated with my seeming inability to interact with a character, and in IV I hadn't tried something I could have sworn I already had.

My only two drawbacks with the game:

1) The inventory suuuuuucks. Ugh. I wish they'd changed this for the remaster. As is, you have to cycle through Manny pulling each object out of his coat before finding the one you want. A better way: another screen opens, all the objects appear as small tiles and you can then select the one you want.

2) More nitpicky: something happens at the beginning of Year II that's always bugged me. Or rather Manny's lack of reaction to it has bugged me. A certain character actively impedes him from following - a move that's seemingly out of character at the time - and he never (far as I can recall) addresses this until he meets up with that character later on. Just a simple 'Why would she do that?! Something must be wrong!' after the cut-scene would have helped. Again unless I missed it, Manny reacts like nothing happened.

Otherwise, a great game. Thanks so much for the remaster. Otherwise I wouldn't have been able to play. (Now bring out DOTT already!)

reviewText:
7/10. I never played this as a kid, but I knew of it as it is quite a famous game. Thought I'd get the Remastered when it came out on Steam to see what I was missing out on. Well, in terms of the story, the world and the cinematic presentation this game is a clear 10/10.

However, the big issue for me is how the storyline is used to guide you into the puzzles/adventure. Essentially the majority of the puzzles are very abstract and there is little to no impetus from the story, no direction to what the game wants you to do. After all, you don't know the bits of the story to come, so some of the things you have to do seem illogical to the player, ie why am I doing this or why am I picking this up, and you often come by a part-solution simply by clicking on every single thing in the room and seeing how they interact with your inventory. Lots of trial and error...which isn't really puzzle solving, but grinding by chance.

For example, in Year 2 by talking to characters in game, you work out that you need a Union licence, tools for Glottis and you need to get rid of a sailor so that you can take his place on the boat.
The licence and tools are fine. But to get rid of the sailor you go through this super abstract puzzle sequence where you end up needing a metal detector, a set of the sailor's ID dog tags, some golden alcohol and a morgue doctor/coroner.
None of this is tied together logically with cut scene storyline, and neither by talking to the other characters.
None of the items make sense to pick up, since they are extremely odd items for achieving the goal of getting rid of the sailor.
So basically you can stumble across the solution bit by bit, but at no time do you play the sequence with the mindset of  I think I should try this or this". It is more like "I have golden alcohol
date: does it work on this item
recommended: does it work in this situation" Click click click
hoursPlayed: trial and error.\n\nThe most playable levels are easily Years 3 and 4
voteText: where it seems the developers put a lot more effort into the storyline and tying together the puzzle sequences/what you are meant to do with the story. It isn't spoon fed to you
helpfulPercent: and the puzzles are still a bit abstract
votesHelpful: but it is more clear what your goals are and the actions you do make more sense when you are doing them.\nYears 1 and 2 however
votesTotal: are simply weird for most part. There is often no clear goal given to you which in other puzzle games is usually given by characters or storyline
votesFunny: ie "We need to get over to that island". Hence find a way to get there.\n\nOverall for a puzzle game
commentsCount: I found this to be very hard
column16: not mainly because of puzzle difficulty
column17: but because of the lack of said puzzle context. Monkey Island
column18: the Nancy Drew series
column19: the Sherlock Holmes series and Machinarium are all more logical puzzle/adventure games.\nI still enjoyed the game
column20: but it seemed more like grinding than puzzle solving at times."

reviewText:
There's not much you can say about this game that hasn't already been said. It's a classic of the genre, with classic written in big bold letters. Even if you're not a fan of the point and click it's an experience, a gem in video game and storytelling history.
***
They haven't changed much from the original but that's the whole point of having a remaster: updated the graphics, added some extras in terms of Tim and the team talking about their ideas and how they worked on the game, and made Grim mouse-friendly. Basically, they made it available to new players and threw in something for the old-timers.

P.S. If you're a completionist, you might want to set the game to tank controls from the first instant you run it and talk to every character about everything. That should get you around 100% achievement of the achievements. Also, use your save slots wisely, there are only 8 of them and you'd do well to keep a save point at the beginning of every year" (level) so that you have a go-to point in case you missed something and aren't planning to replay the whole adventure in the near future."

reviewText: One of the best point & click adventure game ever made without any doubt, it's good to see this classic gems revived and still selling, it makes me feel something could be done in a future thinking in a sequel. In terms of new stuff the work of Double Fine is just not good enough, some rework was done on the 3D textures, but you can only notice it when you press the backspace button, there you say: ahhh, so, IT IS different after all...\nI can say the coolest thing is the team commentary. As a developer it's nice to hear technical difficulties the team had to deal with at that time and there is funny stuff like when Tim tells that the Celso's voice actor thought it was an audition for Star Wars: Episode one. Concept art is also good, and I can say that besides that you can control it with the mouse (although I used the good old tank control system from the original version) and fonts, and nothing else was done (maybe some digitalization of the soundtrack but I couldn't tell), I don't think this few new features justifies a relaunch for a 15 USD price but I can say that as a fan of the franchise I totally paid for it to support it, nowadays you can find lame ports for mobile devices of SNES games selling for more than 10 USD so I think it's ok.

reviewText:
Now here's another case where I miss the thumb-in-the-middle-button.

On the good side:
Grim Fandango is a unique, funny, imaginative point and click adventure from the creators of Monkey Island, Day of the Tentacle and a myriad of other great games from Lucas Studios. The voice acting is above average and the characters and dialogues are great. The game looks good, albeit still quite dated, which doesn't impair my appreciacion of it. The navigation is very end of 90's which is unavoidable as all 'high resolution' 3D games of the time had to work with fixed backgrounds. The game works great on a story level.

On the bad side:
My biggest gripe with this game is the puzzles, which are typical for this type of games, specially from the Lucas/Schafer team: they are just too freaking hard to figure out. There is almost never a hint to how to solve a puzzle and logic doesn't help a lot either, so the player ends up walking around and around, trying every item he collected on every possible thing in the game and also going through every possible dialog. As there is only one path for the player, one may very well end up going around and around for hours before finally finding the missing clue. Not eactly my idea of fun, so I ended up playing the game with a walkthrough so I could at least enjoy the story (so far – I haven't finished it yet).

On a general verdict: this game is for nostalgics and for people who don't get mad at searching for a dumb puzzle piece for hours. That was okay, maybe, in '97, but nowadays, we players expect games to be a bit smarter than that. So let's say this game is from the Dark Ages of games where the player was considered smart if he had the patience to spend hours with dumb try-and-error procedures. Like many games from the Schafer team, the game doesn't actually give the player a chance to actually be smart to solve a puzzle. Instead, it leads him down a path where he will feel miserable because clues look like they could be solved with logic, but they can't. You just have to try over and over until you finally get your reward.
As I said already: not really my kind of fun. I might play through this game with a walkthrough, though.

reviewText:
Grim Fandango is a unique adventure game with a very engaging story.  The puzzles are mostly fun to solve, yet there are some quirky ones.  Character interaction is ecelent, with a lot of interesting dualogue that is fully voiced.  The plot of the game evolves as you progress and it has some surprises in store.

Graphically the game aged pretty well for a 15+ year old title.   It was the first game where I saw animated hands with individual fingers, mostly in older games hands were just oven mits.  Clothing looks like it's worn and not just painted on, which was also a first for me.  The remastered version does a great job of bringing back anti aliasing and adds higher definition textures to the 3D models.  Since the backgrounds are 2D they are still in 3:4 ascpect ratio, but the do add some nice looking borders on the sides to make it less jarring on the eyes.

The story is this game's strong point and it will stay with you years after finishing it.

reviewText:
I only had the original CDR in German and it would crash constantly. It's really nice to have a childhood game back and in a newer state. Graphics look great but still retain the soul of the original game. I'm extremely pleased. And funnily enough, the dubbing sounds exactly the same in English.

Grim Fandango is great with subtleties when it comes to the gameplay, and sometimes the tediousness get’s a bit too…. tedious. But that’s what, for me, helps create the charm of this world. It has its own logic and process and it’s really nice once you start to think like the game. And it’s a good sized game. If you’re on your first play through, or like me, picking it up after a few years, it is extremely time consuming. And I see that as something positive. It harder to get bored with the game and, especially since I love it so much, it means I won't be dissapointed if it's completed too soon.

(Plush the mashup of Art Deco with Dios De Lost Muertos is quite lovely in a non appropriative way)

reviewText: Wow. I may have only speny 11 hours on this, but those 11 hours are some of the best I've spent in ANY video game. Not only is it funny, charming, and it's incrediablely witty dialouge between characters will lure you so much to talk and interact with everything in sight to hear the wonderful voice actiong, but this game is also very deep and creative with the premises the game take inspiration from. Manny Calevera is now one of my favorite protagonists in any game. To see this game do SO well years after it's commercial flop in 1998 (correct me if I'm wrong), but also see it's visuals revamped is absolutely stunning to the eyes. After playing around with the rendering to see differences, I can say that the remastered version definately gives the characters (and the characters only) a GREAT facelift. The models may seem jagged, and the backgrounds remain the same and some animations run at 30 fps, I think  it's something that still leaves the game with an authentic 90's PC gaming that just gives me a nostalgia chill no matter what. My only problem is that the game soft locked" on me during Chapter/Year 1 while switching between fullscreen mode and windowed mode

reviewText:
Fantastic game.

Sadly I never got to play the original, so there was no nostalgia factor when I played.

However that doesn't stop this from being a great game.

Parts can be iffy, ie voice acting.  When they start singing it makes me want to clog my ears.  But the story, the jokes, and the puzzles are what this game is about.  You might not sleep at night because you can't figure out what the hell the wheelbarrow does, but when you give it a few days rest and try again you can overcome the obstacles the game sets in front of you.  Of course, a lesser man has google, but what's the fun in that?

9/10, lost some sleep.  But great game.

reviewText:
MY BACKGROUND: Sometime in the 90's I read a games magazine and the front cover was Grim Fandango. I never played the game back then, but somehow the cover stuck in my mind. Some years later I was browsing the Internet if I could buy the game, but I didn't find it anywhere. Now a few months back I found the game Remastered in Steam so I had to buy it and try it. The game is remastered so it kinda reviwed the old game back to life. It still looks old, but remastering the game makes it playable for a first timer. I think that if you play a really old game today, there must be a nostalgy factor in it or otherwise it's just going to suck for you. Remastering the game to 21th century makes games playable even without earlier experiences.

ACTUAL REVIEW: This is a point and click game which I very much enjoy. If you're not into point and clicks, this game is not for you. The game is an adventure game with lots of dialogues and humour and you advance in the game by completing puzzles. I love how the main character speaks English in a funny accent with Spanish words here and there. Love it. So far the story is very funny and I am eager to complete the story asap.

The only negative thing in the game for me is the puzzles. They didn't age too well. They are illogical and impossible. I can not complete the game without a walkthrough which I am going to use for the whole game. The story and the jokes is what I wanna experience and by using a walkthrough to solve the impossible puzzles I am gonne get just that.

Really happy that they remastered this old title for me to play and have a good time. I suggest though that you buy this game on a sale and not for the full price.

reviewText: While this is not much of a remaster (trust me this was just an excuse to get the game back up and selling) the game is fantastic. I REALLY enjoy point and click adventures. A lot nowadays are really good on story and pacing, the advenuring, mystery puzzle solving, has become really simplistic. Point and click adventures of the 90's were fun problem solvers but the stories were really simple and were mainly comedies. This is the best of both worlds. The puzzles are incredibly fun to solve and the story is so intresting. It is a mix of a mystery comedy sort that was surpursingly keeping me on toes and invested the whole time. The world of the dead is a fantastic angel to work with. All in all if you are a guy that is big on presentation graphicly, this may not be the game for you. If you are going through a 90's throwback phase, enjoy a really good point and click adventure game, or just want to hear an interesting story, this is a must buy.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
First of all I must start this review by saying this game's reputation is very well earned with an excellent plot, interesting characters and a very interesting atmosphere, it's just what you would expect for a game about death and the afterlife.

HOWEVER I do have a bone to pick with it(no pun intended) and that is that at crucial times the controls(specially with a controller) feel rather choppy, the game doesn't give you ANY indications or hints of what to do or where to go, I mean I hate it when a game holds your hand but I think I hate it more when the game doesn't have the slightest hints on what to do and this game has a lot of stuff that give no indications or any hints like, potential spoiler alert, the coat check part how the ♥♥♥♥ are you supposed to know lengua 22 means except by trial and error.
About the choppy controls, those are more evident when driving anything(Glottis Hot Rod, the forklift you name it, I must praise Mr Schafer for the good design in his games, I really get hooked on the story but a good story pales a lot when the controls aren't good.

Overall I must say I both love and hate this game, the story is well written and interesting but the game choppy controls and having little to no hints whatsoever can make for a truly exasperating experience
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I finally have played this game after wanting to for years. I was not disappointed. This is a very unique and well thought out story with well fleshed out (pardon the pun) characters. My favourite is Glottis. You'll see why once you start playing. Some of the puzzles can be slightly tricky to get right, but none of them are overly difficult. I love the accents, the noir feel to some environments, the laugh out loud moments, and Glottis.

This is definitely a game that everyone who enjoys classic adventure games that have a good story, great character development, humour, and good puzzles. There is not a whole lot of replayability, but then neither do most adventure games.

I give this a 9/10. Viva La Revolucion!
